title: 105_s1461
content: The Act may be cited as the "JUMP Ahead Act of 1997". Congress recognizes the need for mentoring programs to support at-risk youth living in areas plagued by drug use and crime, often coming from single-parent homes. Mentoring provides a vital bond of commitment and mutual respect that can lead these young individuals towards a better future through dedicated relationships. Effective mentoring programs can significantly reduce alcohol and drug use, improve school performance, enhance relationships, and decrease violent behavior. Despite the growth in mentoring initiatives, millions of children in the US could benefit from having a mentor. Many innovative programs have received funding grants through the Federal JUMP program. Millions of vulnerable American children are not being reached by mentoring programs like JUMP, risking losing a generation to drugs, crime, and unproductive lives. SEC. 3. JUVENILE MENTORING GRANTS. The Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act of 1974 is amended to include goals aimed at discouraging at-risk youth from engaging in illegal activities and promoting personal responsibility among them. The Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act of 1974 is amended to include goals to discourage at-risk youth from illegal activities and promote personal responsibility. Grants under this amendment aim to increase at-risk youth participation in education, community service, and provide general guidance. Each grant is limited to $200,000 over a maximum of 3 years, with an authorization of $50,000,000 annually from 1999 to 2002. SEC. 4. IMPLEMENTATION AND EVALUATION GRANTS. The Administrator of the Office of Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention may make grants to national organizations or agencies serving youth for a multisite demonstration project to compare mentoring models and provide innovative programs. The Office of Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention may make grants for a demonstration project to compare mentoring models and develop best practices. This includes research, evaluation, screening standards, and volunteer recruitment for mentoring programs. $5,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 1999 to 2002 for this purpose. SEC. 5. EVALUATIONS; REPORTS. The Attorney General will contract with an evaluating organization to conduct rigorous evaluations of programs assisted under this Act. Minimum criteria will be established for evaluating the programs, focusing on implementation and impact on participants. The Attorney General will designate a "Juvenile Mentoring Program of the Year" based on evaluations and other criteria. Grant recipients must submit reports on the impact of the program on participants, schools, communities, and youth served. The Attorney General will submit an annual report on programs assisted under the Act and evaluate grants awarded under the Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act. The Attorney General will submit an annual report on programs assisted under the Act, evaluating grants awarded under the Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act, focusing on reducing juvenile delinquency, gang participation, school dropout rates, and improving academic performance of juveniles.
